results.title: On the level: a little help from my friends
results.brief_description: Two boys work part-time packing fish on the docks. However, one continually abuses his friendship with the other by failing to keep appointments and not honoring promises. He dismisses his unreliability by saying that his friend will understand and that’s what friends are for. His casual attitude towards his responsibility eventually causes both himself and his friend to lose their jobs. A good discussion starter for addressing issues about expectations of friendship, dishonesty and sexism. Suitable for middle secondary level.

results.title: Libraries and the pursuit of happiness
results.creator_credit: Cheryl Jefferson and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows the modern library as an active learning center and a valuable public resource offering a variety of services, including book lending, excersise classes, special collections and assisting the disabled. Visits libraries throughout the United States.

results.title: An Approach for developing mathematical concepts
results.creator_credit: Dennis Claringbold and Melbourne College of Advanced Education. Media Production Centre
results.brief_description: Ross McKeown conducts a maths lesson for Year 2 students from Boronia Heights Primary School using the following steps. 1. Introduce concepts using concrete materials. 2. Games to reinforce concept. 3. Further practice and revision of concept. 4. Evaluation and recording of progress. Uses the concept of place value to demonstrate these techniques.

results.title: Face to face: dealing with conflict
results.creator_credit: Agency for Instructional Television and Educational Film Center
results.brief_description: Highlights the need to be aware of one’s limitations and to know when to say “no”. An adolescent girl at high school takes on too much work on the local school magazine and as a result her school work suffers. Unable to handle her poor examination results, she lashes out angrily and irrationally at those around her. Raises issues regarding the need to accept responsibility for one’s actions and to be assertive as opposed to weak or aggressive.

results.title: Don't think I don't think. Fair enough
results.creator_credit: Dale Baker, Hodja Ed Res Co-op, La Trobe University, Open Channel Productions and Preston Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: 1. “Don’t think I don’t think”. A workshop of the 1981 South Pacific Regional Conference on Mental Retardation. 2. “Fair enough”. The experiences of students finding difficulty in mantaining dignity and rights in the face of “hidden curricula” of school.

results.title: Correction procedures
results.brief_description: Demonstrates and provides correction techniques used when assessing written work to provide immediate feedback on children’s progress. Shows how to diagnose incorrect responses by response type, how to recognize the type of error and three basic correction procedures.

results.title: Presentation techniques
results.brief_description: Provides materal suitable for assisting teachers to develop the skills they need in the presentation of Direct Instruction Materials. Notes scripts and formats, signals and group responses, how to present a lesson, how to practice on one’s own, how to use sample lessons and the importance of corrections. No other credits available

results.title: Basics of direct instruction
results.brief_description: Gives an overview of the Direct Instruction technique which was developed in the 1960’s to develop successful students with a positive approach and works on problem solving skills so students learn to learn. Skills are broken into sub-skills until mastered and integrated. Notes the goals, assumptions and characteristics of Direct Instruction programmes, provides a brief description of teaching techniques and how to prepare a Direct Instruction program.
